Fields.DialogueText: Ciao, Capitano!

Fields.MenuText: Ciao, Garibaldi.
Excuse me?
I'm sorry, I don't speak... uh...

Fields.DialogueText: I love it when you speak Italian, Capitano!
Sorry, Capitano! Thought I'd see if you knew Italian.
You must not have had your coffee yet. It's Italian, silly.
Why are you speaking in Italian now? Your command of English is exemplary.
Well, I was unsure how the crew would respond beforehand, with them speaking such a mix of languages.
Now that I've come to know everyone a bit better, though, I feel more comfortable speaking my native tongue!
Were you really worried about the crew not liking you because of something as simple as language?
Well, the tensions between nations and the Morganas are high enough as is. Even language can make people paranoid.
All of us have to put aside our differences for the common good. Rest assured, myself and the crew are happy to be with you, Garibaldi.
Grazie, Capitano!
@BATTLE
So... why is it pronounced that way?
What way?
Ciao. It's sounds like chow, another word for food...
Hmm... you know, I'm not quite sure...
I hear the food is good in Italy, but to pronounce your greeting like that... well, it sounds a little ridiculous.
It doesn't sound so ridiculous for Italian speakers, you know.
*ahem* Why are you two sitting in my quarters?
Ciao, Capitano! I was trying to teach some Italian to this sailor here. I figured it would be fun.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like a good idea! Maybe he'll learn something new.
I think we have more pressing matters to attend to. You know... a war...
What has he learned so far?

Fields.DialogueText: I agree! It's also a good way to pass the time.
I haven't forgotten about the war, Capitano. I just thought this would be a good way to keep the crew on their toes. Learning something new keeps minds active!
So much! He's really getting the hang of it!
*ALARM*
As interesting as this is, we have to get to the bridge. Come on, Garibaldi.
Yes, Capitano!
@BATTLE
I think this may be the first time I've heard you hum Bersaglieri's Fanfare on the bridge.
Really?
Well... the battle did just end. I thought we could use some victory music!

Fields.MenuText: It certainly seems to inspire the crew.
I'm glad you're still humming. It's soothing to hear.
That song really is your favorite, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: I've even caught some of them humming it to themselves. Always puts a smile on my face.
It's important to have something that soothes the mind. Bersaglieri's Fanfare always makes my worries vanish.
What's not to like about it? It's a whimsical piece!
You know, I don't know that I've ever heard it performed professionally. Mostly, I just know it from your humming.
Well, I always say you haven't heard true music until you've heard Bersaglieri's Fanfare performed by a full orchestra.
Maybe, one day, I will.
If you do, promise you'll invite me to come too!
Of course, Garibaldi.
@BATTLE
Capitano, wait!
What is it?
You forgot to get orange slices for yourself! I'll be right back!
What do you have against her?
I don't trust her, that's all.
There's more to it than that, be honest.
Think about it. These Belles are every bit as strong as the Morganas. What happens if we win the war, and the Belles turn on us after? We won't stand a chance.
You're sounding paranoid.
It's something to consider.

Fields.MenuText: Anything wrong with your meal, gentlemen?
You know, disparaging the war effort is generally frowned upon in these parts.

Fields.DialogueText: N-n-no, Captain! We just finished!
So sorry, Captain! We'd never do anything like that!
Get back to work before I put both of you on cleaning duty. Now.
Yes, Captain.
Sorry, Captain.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Incoming fire!
All hands, get to your stations. We need to end these Morganas at all costs!
@BATTLE
The battle's already over?
The Morganas have turned tail... I'd say we're victorious once again!
Excellent! Really, I can't thank all of you on the bridge enough for your service. You've made such strides since we first came together - it really is commendable!
Why, thank you, ma'am...
All of you deserve a reward! Oh, I know! I'll carve a special trinket for everyone tonight! Does anyone have any requests?

Fields.MenuText: Do you really have enough supplies to make gifts for everyone?
Do... do I get something, too?
I'm with Garibaldi. Amazing job everyone!

Fields.DialogueText: You know... I should probably check if I do...
How could I not make you something, Capitano?! Of course you'll get something!
Let's all give a cheer! We won another battle!
I'm off to find my carving knife...
Don't cut off any fingers, Garibaldi.
Ha! As if I would ever.
Hooray!
Morganas approaching, Captain! We need a course of action!
We'll fight...
Head on! Let's show the Morganas what happens when you mess with a unified team!

Fields.MenuText: You heard her! Get going!
Garibaldi, as much as I appreciate your enthusiasm, let me give the orders. Crew, get ready to defend!
Remember, stay strong.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain!
Understood, Captain!
We'll do our best, Captain!
Sorry for...
Interrupting? Just try not to make a habit of it.
Understood. Now let's show these Morganas what we're made of.
@BATTLE
Capitano! It's been a while since we shared a snack. I thought I would surprise you.
Well, that's kind of you, Garibaldi. Come on in.
You know, Garibaldi... you have interesting taste in clothing.
What do you mean by that, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: Well, it isn't traditional military clothing. Why do you dress like that?
No offense, but isn't the style in Italy a little more "refined"?
It's just... why that clothing? It looks like something out of South America.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, it's comfortable, for one. I also love the style that the Gauchos introduced.
It is a bit different. But I've chosen this style of clothing for a reason.
You have an eye for fashion! It did originate from South America. The Gauchos wore this type of clothing.
It's the garb of cattle ranchers. To me, it represents a simple life in the countryside.
You did mention how you wanted to settle down after the war.
And when I do, this is the type of clothing I'll be wearing. These clothes, they represent bravery, generosity, even nobility.
And you think that imagery is crucial in times like these?
Ah, you know me too well.
Think I'd look good in something like that?
Hmm... oh! Would you look at the time?! I have to run!
@BATTLE
Garibaldi? Is that you humming?
You're getting close!
It is a catchy tune. I wish I could hear it played.
The next time we go to dock, I'll ask around to see if we can get a hold of a...
Am I interrupting?
No! I was just spreading the love of Bersaglieri's Fanfare.
Captain, do you think that we could get our hands on a record when we refuel and restock our supplies?

Fields.MenuText: No promises, but I'll see what I can do.
We could use some more background noise. Sure, I'll track one down.
I don't know. We don't want too many distractions on the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me know if there's anything I can do to help!
I cannot wait for you to hear it!
We've all been doing great work. I think the crew deserves it.
*ALARM*
Get to your stations. After the battle, I'll look into it.
Thanks, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Garibaldi? What are you doing here?
Ciao, Capitano! My usual spot for carving is a bit too noisy for me to focus, and I thought your quarters might be more quiet.
What are you carving?
I'm trying to make a little boat.
It looks complicated. How do you do it?
Practice. A lot of practice. Would you like to join? I could teach you a few things.

Fields.MenuText: Sure, I'll give it a go.
Will this take long?
I'm not sure. I'm really only an artist with a gun.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent! Take a seat and we'll start our first lesson. You have paper and pencil for taking notes, don't you?
It's simpler than it looks, I promise. Take a seat.
Don't worry! With me by your side, you'll be done in no time.
*Some Time Later*
There! See? It wasn't that hard.
So, now what?
Now, it's yours! You may keep it, or give it as a gift to whomever you choose.
Thanks, Garibaldi.
@BATTLE
The resupply went smoothly, Captain. If there's nothing else, I'd like to go back to the bridge.
Excellent. You're dismissed.
Hee... here it is!
Where did you get this?
I asked a few of the crew members to see if they couldn't track down a cheap record player on the docks. And they did!
Not bad, Garibaldi.
Now, all that we need is a record of Bersaglieri's Fanfare.

Fields.MenuText: I looked around while we were at dock but couldn't find any copies. We'll have to give it another go next time.
Drat. I forgot to look while we were at dock!
How are we going to get our hands on a record of it?

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds like a plan.
Come on, Capitano! I'm not getting any younger here.
We? You said you were going to take care of it!
I promise, I'll track down one sooner or later.
Good! I'm glad to hear it.
@BATTLE
See that sailor over there, Capitano?
I do.
I just found out he's from my hometown of Taranto. Isn't that something?

Fields.MenuText: It must be nice to have someone from home nearby.
I don't know that I've ever heard you mention your hometown.
What did he think about meeting a Belle native to his hometown?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not much for homesickness, but I will admit, it's nice having him here.
Taranto? Oh, it's so wonderful, Capitano. The weather is mild all year long, the skies and sea blue - it's perfection.
I think he was caught off guard at first, but after a while, it was like we had known each other our entire lives!
Do he have any word on how the nation of Italy is doing?
Garibaldi?
I'm not sure that the original Giuseppe Garibaldi would look kindly on Il Duce, Capitano. It's... it's difficult.
Are you all right, Garibaldi?
...I will be. I just wish there was more I could do to help my country.
You put your life on the line on a daily basis for them. That's not nothing.
... I suppose that's right.
@BATTLE
Capitano! You won't believe what I found!
Really? Because I don't think you'll believe what I...
That's right! A record of Bersaglieri's Fanfare!
Wait. What were you about to say? And what do you have in that package there?
... Another copy of Bersaglieri's Fanfare. Haha! Looks as if we both found what we were looking for during our most recent time at dock.
Ah...
Well, I suppose one will get to be your private copy, and one will be available for the crew at large.
Excellent idea, Capitano! Ah!

Fields.MenuText: Calm down, Garibaldi.
Two copies... I should have known something like this would happen.
Where did you find your copy?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sorry! I'm just beyond excited! You and the crew finally get to experience the song as it should be heard!
Just goes to show you, you shouldn't have spent so much time trying to track it down in the first place.
At that little corner shop right next to the dock. It was just barely close enough for me to visit.
*ALARM*
Really? Now?
Come on, Garibaldi! Let's move!
All right, all right.
@BATTLE
Hey, now.
Hee.
Same here.
Really? We must have just missed each other...
Capitano, I brought us a snack again! Just oranges this time.
Oranges sound good. Have a seat.
Something wrong? You haven't had an orange slice yet...
Remember the crew member from my hometown?
What about him?
Well... he received a letter from home. From the sounds of things, the political situation over there is even worse than I knew.
Garibaldi...
Capitano, do you believe mankind is capable of peaceably living with one another, despite our differences?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. You've shown me that people can band together, no matter their background.
I think it's certainly possible. Right now, though, we have to give our full attention to the Morganas.
Let's finish this war first.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitano. I do try my absolute best.
You're right.
I understand. Sometimes, we just have to focus on immediate threats.
Orange slice?
Thank you, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Capitano! There seems to be not much to do at the moment. Want to be the first person on the ship to listen to Bersaglieri's Fanfare?
Sure. I'm surprised you've been able to wait this long.
I'm surprised myself. Sit, sit. I'll set everything up.
Here we go! Be honest and tell me what you think.
*Some Time Later*
Well, what did you think?

Fields.MenuText: It's quite the impressive piece! I see why you hum it so much...
Those horns are so... bouncy! I don't think I've heard anything like that before...
Stirring! The crew will love it.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'm so happy you agree!
Well, it's unique! Of course you haven't heard anything like it before.
I'm sure they will!
I'll move it to the cafeteria, I can't wait for the crew to hear!
*ALARM*
Maybe you can wait a little.
@BATTLE
I hear music! What's going on?
Ciao, Capitano! I brought the record player out here and had some of the crew come out to listen.
And are they liking it?
See for yourself!
This is pretty good!
It definitely has its own distinct sound.
See? I told them that, after all of their hard work, they deserved a break. And I think taking some time to listen has really done the trick.

Fields.MenuText: You're right! They deserve some time to relax.
As long as they understand this is a rare occasion, it's fine by me.
Hopefully this won't make the crew lazier...

Fields.DialogueText: That's what I thought. You should come and join us, Capitano!
They do, they do. You know this crew is one of the hardest working in the fleet.
If anything, their morale will be better than ever. Trust me on this one.
@BATTLE
Sure, why not?
Ciao, Capitano!
And ciao to you.
You know, you're not the only one humming that tune anymore. I'm hearing it all over the mess hall.
I know, isn't it great?!

Fields.MenuText: You know, a little variety in song selection might be nice.
I have to admit, I miss when it was just you...
I think the crew has really warmed up to you, Garibaldi.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, pah, Capitano.
That's sweet of you to say!
I'm happy to say I think so too.
You know, I'm going to miss this one day.
What?
The crew, the victories, and you, Capitano.
You know what? When that day comes, I think I'll miss it too.
@BATTLE
Captain, may I speak with you for a moment?
Sure.
Thank you, Captain.
What's this about? Is there a problem?
There is. It's about the Belle.
Garibaldi?
I just don't think she's good for our crew.

Fields.MenuText: You must be joking! She's kept the energy on this ship high. Are you sure you aren't the one with the problem?
Why would you think that?
Has the crew's performance been affected?

Fields.DialogueText: I meant no offense. I just think the crew might get soft due to her influence.
She keeps giving the crew free time. I'm worried they might get soft.
Well, no. Not yet.
If that's all, you're dismissed.
Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE
A little free time here and there won't hurt anyone, so long as it doesn't become excessive.
If that changes in the future, let me know. Otherwise, please do your best to work with Garibaldi, in spite of your difference in views on crew discipline.
Capitano! I've been waiting for you!
Sorry, I was busy. What do you need?
Well, you've been so busy, I figured you could use a break! How about I give you another carving lesson.
Sure, I would like that.
*Some Time Later*
So, I've been noticing that one of the officers is always in a bad mood...
Ah, yes. I know who you're talking about. He talked to me not too long ago. He's concerned about the crew.
What is he worried about?

Fields.MenuText: He's afraid that you're making them lazy. That by doing all these kind gestures, they're becoming weak.
He's just jealous that he can't inspire the crew like you can.
I don't know what his problem is. But he'll get over it.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? Come to think of it, I haven't made anything for him yet. Maybe I should do something for him.
But why get jealous? We're on the same team.
I hope so. Maybe a carving will put him in a good mood.
*ALARM*
Looks like this half-finished bear carving will have to wait until later.
I don't know, Capitano. He's kind of cute, as is!
@BATTLE
I'm not sure...
So why are you bringing me to the sick bay?
One of the crew members was injured in our last fight. I told him that I would have you cheer him up!
*ALARM*
Maybe we can schedule that a little later...
@BATTLE
Surprise! Look who came all the way from the bridge to pay you a visit!
C-Captain? What are you doing here?

Fields.MenuText: I heard you were feeling a bit down, thought I'd come and thank you for your service.
You'll get better in no time! I'm looking forward to having you back on the bridge!

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. I look forward to getting back to work.
You do a great job at keeping us together, Captain. Thank you.
Oh! Your candle is almost all melted! Don't worry, I'll make you a new one. I have a new scent I've been meaning to try out.
That's kind of you, Garibaldi. Thank you.
Of course! Now, get some rest. The Capitano and I will return to check on you in a bit.
You really are good with the crew, Garibaldi.
They're like family to me. How could I not look out for them?
Officer?
Oh... Garibaldi. Hello.
I've been meaning to speak with you.
You... you have?
Look, I know you aren't too fond of me...
I don't know what you're talking ab--
So I was carving something, and I made this for you!
What is this?
It's a medal! I wanted to make something unique just for you! Also, If I've done anything to upset you, I want to apologize...
What are you two up to? Any reason you're standing outside my quarters?
I was just heading out... um... thank you, Garibaldi.
My pleasure!

Fields.MenuText: Trying to make nice, Garibaldi?

Fields.DialogueText: Succeeding, I'd say.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: You're treating that officer better than they deserve.
How can anybody have issues with you? You're just so damn good with people, it boggles the mind.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe he didn't earn the kindness, but he needs it.
Different types have different needs, but all I can do is be my best, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Capitano! I'm heading back down to the sick bay to check in on our friend... you want to join?
Sure, let's go see how he's doing.
Excellent!
Any word on his condition?
The doctors say he should be back on duty before we know it. I'd like to think that your presence alone was enough to revitalize him.

Fields.MenuText: I'd say it had more to do with your presence than mine.
Really? I only visited him once.
I'm glad I could help!

Fields.DialogueText: That's sweet of you, Capitano! But I do believe that you were responsible!
Never underestimate the power of morale, Capitano.
I like to think there's nothing better than an involved, thoughtful leader.
You know, Garibaldi, I've been meaning to ask you about the officer. How are things there?
Oh! After we chatted...
*ALARM*
I guess we'll chat later...
@BATTLE
Capitano! Care for another wood carving lesson?
Sure, what are we going to make?
Well, how about another ship?

Fields.MenuText: We can't do something more abstract?
I'm not surprised...
Are we going to put it in a bottle afterwards?

Fields.DialogueText: One step at a time!
Sorry, Capitano! I promise you'll like this!
Hmm... It doesn't work quite like that, Capitano...
Well, let's get started.
*Some Time Later*
You're making progress!
You think so?
Look at that sail you've carved. I do think it's one of the best sails I've ever seen.
You just can't help but be encouraging, can you?
Nope! It's ingrained in my personality.
Well, the ship is better for it.
Thanks, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Just help me place it on the desk...
Look, this thing is heavy...  give me a minute...
I want it to be a surprise for the Capitano! Hurry!
Come on! You can do it! I believe in you! We just have...
*ahem*
Hello, Capitano!

Fields.MenuText: What is this all about?
Need my help?
Garibaldi, what's everybody doing in my cabin?

Fields.DialogueText: Umm... nothing...
N-no! It's quite all right!
Well, you see...
I picked up this record player at the last port we were in. You work so hard, I thought it might be nice for you to be able to play music whenever you like.
Well, that's thoughtful of you, Garibaldi. But I have some paperwork I need to see to...
Oh, of course! Come on, Officer. Let's not bother the Capitano.
I see you two are getting along better.
I told you I succeeded at making nice!
@BATTLE
Is this shipment of coffee correct?
Let me check... yes, it is!
So where am I putting all of this?
Put it in a place where none of the crew will find it. I can't have them getting into it before the capitano and I have a chance to give it a try.
You know this stuff was pretty expensive...
After the capitano and I have some, we'll give some to sick bay, and the rest to the galley. Hopefully, that way, anyone who wants a taste will get one.

Fields.MenuText: Plotting again, you two?
Should I be worried about whatever is going on here?
I don't think I want to know what's happening...

Fields.DialogueText: Ciao, Capitano! No, of course not! We're just sorting out some cargo that we picked up recently...
This is me we're talking about, Capitano! I would never plan anything nefarious.
Don't sound so pessimistic, Capitano!
*ALARM*
Stay out of trouble, you two.
Of course.
@BATTLE
Surprise!
Garibaldi? What are you doing inside my quarters? What's going on?
Well, I wanted to thank you for being such a good leader. So I had one of the officers get some coffee from Italy!
That's...
Also, I brought in Bersaglieri's Fanfare for us to listen to! It's time for you to put up your feet and relax a little.

Fields.MenuText: That's very kind of you, Garibaldi. Sure, let's try that coffee.
That coffee smells heavenly...
So this is why you've been sneaking around recently?

Fields.DialogueText: Yay! Let's get started.
I'm excited!
You caught me, Capitano!
Garibaldi, you are an extraordinary Belle... I don't know what this ship would do without you.
Grazie, Capitano. Here's your cup. Careful, it's hot!
Thank you, Garibaldi. Let's toast. To a swift end to this war?
And the best crew in the fleet?
Hear, hear!
Hear, hear!
